data.title: MR. SIMON FRASER'S DEATH.
data.meta_description: Mr. Simon Fraser, late M. L. A. and Chairman of Committees of the Legislative Assembly, died at 8 o'clook yesterday morning at his residence, Torbrack, ...
data.text:
Mr Simon Fraser, late M L A and Chairman

of Committees of the Legislative

Assembly, died at 8 o'clock yesterday

morning at his residence, Torbiack, High

gate Hill. He was taken ill on Christmas

Eve, and although later on he recovered

somewhat on the morning of Christmas

Day his illness became serious, and a few days

afterwards it was evident that no hopes

could he entertained of his recovery

Mr Fraser was a very old and highly respected

citizen of Brisbane He was born in Invot

ness about 1824, and was educated

in his native town, but at an early age

went to England, spending some time

in Reading, Boston, and Liverpool At the

latter place he carried on the business

of an ironmonger until he decided

to emigrate He came to Queensland in

1862, and started business in Brisbane as an

auctioneer A year or so afterwards he entered

into partnership in the same business

with Mr J T Buckland, the title of the firm

being Fraser and Buckland About ten) years

afterwards the pm courtship was dissolved, and

Mr Fraser continued in business by himself

until his oldest son, Alexander T. Fraser,

joined it two or three years ago

Mr Fraser had also during the past

twenty j ears, and up to the last general

election, boonidontidod with the Parliamentary

life of the colony He first entered the Legislative

Assembly as member for North Brisbane

in 1878, his colleagues in the representation

of the city being Dr O'Doherty and

Mr T P Pugh, the latter gentleman being

now police-magistrate at Warwick In

1872 he represented Bundanba, and in 1880

was elected member for South Brisbane, Mrs

Gooding Mr AugusMiokuy During the last

Parliament he was Chairman of Committees,

but at the late general election he was defeated

for South Brisbane by a very narrow majority

by) Mr Lind A subsequent appeal to the

Elections Tribunal failed to alter the result of

the election Mt I favor has always sat and

voted with the Liberal party in the House

Although a dull speaker, he was greatly 10

spected by his fellow-members, while all finely

gave him credit for the strictest impartiality

and conscientiousness in the discharge of his

duties as Chairman of Committees in private

life the deceased gentleman had many friends,

who highly esteemed him for his quiet and

unassuming demeanour, and for the interest he

took in the well-being of those who needed a

helping hand He took a great interest in

Church work, and had been connected with

the Grey - street Congregational Church
